I could have solved the problem better by double-checking my calculations and ensuring that I had added and subtracted the percentages correctly. problem_text:
Context:
The average hours worked per week by residents of Kent were 43.1 for males and 30.9 for females. Their industry of employment was 17.3% retail, 12.4% manufacturing, 11.8% real estate, 10.3% health and social work, 8.9% construction, 8.2% transport and communications, 7.9% education, 6.0% public administration and defence, 5.6% finance, 4.8% other community and personal service activities, 4.1% hotels and restaurants, 1.6% agriculture, 0.8% energy and water supply, 0.2% mining, and 0.1% private households. This is higher than the whole of England for construction and transport/communications, and lower for manufacturing.

Question:
How many percent more was health and social work over energy and water supply and mining combined?

steps.step_response: Yes, breaking down the problem into smaller parts can make it easier to solve.

type_of_step.name: Break down the problem
type_of_step.text: Can I break down the problem into smaller, more manageable parts? Please be concise and professional. Do only this step and do not jump ahead.

steps.step_response: The relevant information is the percentage of employment in health and social work, energy and water supply, and mining in Kent.

type_of_step.name: Identify relevant information
type_of_step.text: What information is relevant to the problem? Please be concise and professional. Do only this step and do not jump ahead.

steps.usefulness_commentary: Identifying the relevant information helped me focus on the necessary data to solve the problem.

steps.step_response:
To solve the problem, we need to add the percentages of employment in energy and water supply and mining, and then subtract the result from the percentage of employment in health and social work. 

So, the calculation would be: 

(10.3% - (0.8% + 0.2%)) = 9.3%

Therefore, health and social work was 9.3% more than energy and water supply and mining combined.
